Answer: The problem is not with the API, but with the way the servlet is being configured. The servlet container is using the default character encoding for the response, which is ISO-8859-1. This is because the servlet container does not know the encoding you specified in the web.xml file.

To fix this, you need to specify the character encoding in the web.xml file. Here is how you can do it:

```xml
<web-app>
    <locale-encoding-mapping-list>
        <locale-encoding-mapping>
            <locale>zh_TW</locale>
            <encoding>utf-8</encoding>
        </locale-encoding-mapping>
    </locale-encoding-mapping-list>
</web-app>
```

This configuration tells the servlet container that the encoding for the locale 'zh_TW' is 'utf-8'. Now, when the servlet container encounters the locale 'zh_TW', it will use the 'utf-8' encoding for the response.

So, in your servlet, you don't need to set the character encoding explicitly. The servlet container will take care of it. You can just write the Chinese characters directly to the response:

```java
public class FeedUpdaterServlet extends HttpServlet {
    public void doGet(HttpServletRequest req, HttpServletResponse resp) throws IOException {
        PrintWriter out = resp.getWriter();
        resp.setContentType("text/html; charset=utf-8");
        out.println("Hello, world!!@!");
        out.println("我是人");  // Chinese character
        out.flush();
        out.close();
    }
}
```

Now, the response should be in the 'utf-8' encoding, which should correctly display the Chinese characters.

Note: The servlet container should be restarted for the changes to take effect.
